data.name: “Pikachu” nudibranch
data.behavior: Conspicuous yellow body with dark-tipped rhinophores and cerata-like appendages.
data.description: Tiny crowd favorite at Bali macro sites.
data.funFact: Nicknamed after the anime character for its color scheme.

data.name: Anthias
data.description: Identified as Anthias

data.name: Banded coral (boxer) shrimp
data.behavior: Forms cleaning stations; long white antennae advertise service.
data.description: Red-and-white banded arms with large chelae.
data.reproduction: Pairs; female carries eggs, larvae planktonic.
data.funFact: Often seen in pairs guarding a crevice like tiny boxers.

data.name: Banded sea krait (yellow-lipped)
data.behavior: Solitary
data.description: Highly venomous but docile. Amphibious lifestyle (land & sea).
data.funFact: Amphibious lifestyle (land & sea)

data.name: Bigfin reef squid
data.behavior: Schooling; rapid color change; pelagic at night.
data.description: Bigfin reef squid: common seagrass near Sanur in Bali
data.funFact: Rapid color changes in schools

data.name: Bird's nest coral
data.behavior: Delicate branching; high-flow habitats; polyps extend at night.
data.description: Bird's nest coral: common current‑swept slopes near Menjangan in Bali
data.funFact: Delicate branches shelter small fish

data.name: Black Damsel
data.description: Identified as Black Damsel

data.name: Blacktip reef shark
data.behavior: Reef patrols; wary of divers; active crepuscular hunter.
data.description: Blacktip reef shark: occasional shallow reefs near Nusa Penida (caution needed) in Bali
data.funFact: Distinct black fin tips

data.name: Blue sea star
data.behavior: Slow grazer/scavenger; regenerates arms; gentle.
data.description: Blue sea star: common shallow reefs near Padang Bai in Bali
data.funFact: Regrows arms; vivid blue

data.name: Blue Tang
data.behavior: Social
data.description: Bright blue surgeonfish with distinctive yellow tail and black markings. Popular in the aquarium trade.
data.funFact: Featured in Finding Nemo as Dory

data.name: Blue-spotted ribbontail ray
data.behavior: Solitary
data.description: Bright blue warning spots, often resting under ledges.
data.funFact: Bright blue warning spots

data.name: Bluebell tunicate
data.behavior: Colonial “little bottles” forming blue clusters.
data.description: Each zooid 0.5–2.5 cm; colonies can carpet patches of reef.
data.lifeSpan: Months to a few years (colonial turnover)
data.reproduction: Hermaphroditic; larvae settle and clone into colonies.
data.funFact: Despite the look, they’re chordates—our distant cousins.

data.name: Bluefin Tuna
data.description: AI-identified as Bluefin Tuna (Thunnus thynnus)

data.name: Bobbit worm (sand striker)
data.diet: Ambush predator on fishes and invertebrates
data.behavior: Buries body; lightning-fast jaws snatch prey.
data.description: Elusive, very long worm seen on night dives; impressive strikes.
data.funFact: Largest specimens approach 3 m—longer than most divers.

data.name: Boulder coral
data.description: Identified as Boulder coral

data.name: Brain Coral
data.description: Identified as Brain Coral

data.name: Brain coral (maze coral)
data.description: Identified as Brain coral (maze coral)

data.name: Brittle stars (typical reef species)
data.behavior: Nocturnal; arms snake out from hiding to feed.
data.description: Slender-armed echinoderms carpeting reefs at night.
data.reproduction: Broadcast spawning; some brood under the disc.
data.funFact: Can jettison arms to escape, then regrow them.

data.name: Broadclub cuttlefish
data.behavior: Color-wave displays; ambushes fish; often diurnal.
data.description: Broadclub cuttlefish: common reefs near Padang Bai in Bali
data.funFact: Dynamic color waves for communication

data.name: Bryde’s whale
data.behavior: Baleen lunge-feeder; three ridges on the head are a field mark.
data.description: Sleek rorqual occasionally transiting Indonesian passages.
data.migration: Regional movements; less migratory than many baleen whales.
data.funFact: Often feeds just below bait balls, pushing prey to the surface.

data.name: Christmas tree worm
data.behavior: Retracts instantly; operculum “door” caps its tube.
data.description: Colorful twin spirals embedded in corals all over Bali reefs.
data.lifeSpan: Years (multi-year residents on the same coral)
data.reproduction: Broadcast spawner; larvae settle on corals and bore a tube.
data.funFact: Populations mirror the health of their host coral colonies.

data.name: Clownfish
data.behavior: Social
data.description: The iconic clownfish is famous for its symbiotic relationship with sea anemones. They are immune to the anemone's stinging cells and provide protection in return.
data.funFact: Sequential hermaphrodites - all clownfish are born male and can change to female

data.name: Coconut octopus
data.behavior: Collects shells; bipedal walking; intelligent, shy.
data.description: Coconut octopus: occasional muck near Amed (caution needed) in Bali
data.funFact: Carries shells as mobile armor

data.name: Collector (pincushion) urchin
data.behavior: Covers itself with debris—hence “collector.”
data.description: Round urchin with short spines; common in shallow habitats.
data.funFact: Self-shading with shells and leaves may reduce UV exposure.

data.name: Common lionfish
data.behavior: Slow ambush predator; spreads fins; venomous spines.
data.description: Common lionfish: common reefs near Tulamben (caution needed) in Bali
data.funFact: Native to Indonesia; invasive in Atlantic

data.name: Common spider conch
data.diet: Algae and biofilm grazed from sand and seagrass blades
data.behavior: Uses its clawed operculum to ‘hop’ across the bottom; active at high tide.
data.description: Large Strombidae sea snail with pink-orange aperture and a flared outer lip that bears finger-like ‘spines’.
data.reproduction: Egg masses laid in gelatinous strings; planktonic larvae before settling.
data.endangered: Not Evaluated globally; locally vulnerable to over-collecting—protected in some MPAs.
data.funFact: Their eyes sit on long stalks and they can ‘jump’ surprisingly far using the operculum as a kickstand.

data.name: Coral
data.description: Identified as Coral

data.name: Crown-of-thorns starfish
data.behavior: Solitary
data.description: Consumes coral tissue rapidly. Report outbreaks to park staff.
data.funFact: Consumes coral tissue rapidly

data.name: Cushion star
data.behavior: Slow grazer; juveniles look like stubby 5-armed stars.
data.description: Pillow-shaped sea star common on tropical Indo-Pacific reefs.
data.funFact: Adults lose the classic star shape as the disc inflates.

data.name: Decorator crab
data.behavior: Attaches sponges and algae as living camouflage.
data.description: Lumpy body masked by encrusting “decorations.”
data.funFact: Will redecorate itself if you gently remove its costume.

data.name: Elephant ear sponge
data.behavior: Large fan-shaped sheets in high-flow corridors.
data.description: Huge yellow to purple fan sponge; microbial symbioses are abundant.
data.funFact: Can exceed 1 m across; natural products from this sponge are studied.

data.name: Feather-duster worm
data.behavior: Extends a circular fan of radioles; snaps back into tube at the slightest disturbance.
data.description: Tube-dwelling polychaete with a brown/tan fan; common on Bali’s sandy seagrass flats.
data.reproduction: Broadcast spawner; planktonic larvae settle and build tubes
data.funFact: That 'feather' is hundreds of tiny tentacles sorting food by size.

data.name: Fimbriated moray
data.behavior: Secretive; usually with just the head protruding from a hole.
data.description: Yellow-green body with dark-rimmed spots and a distinct black margin at the gill opening.
data.funFact: The name refers to the dark ‘fringe’ (fimbriation) edging its spots.

data.name: Flamboyant cuttlefish
data.behavior: Toxic flesh; walks on arms; flashing colors.
data.description: Flamboyant cuttlefish: occasional muck flats near Puri Jati (Lovina) in Bali
data.funFact: Walks on arms with vivid displays

data.name: Flower urchin
data.behavior: Often concealed by “flower” pedicellariae that can sting.
data.description: Among the most venomous urchins; keep wide berth.
data.funFact: Stinging pedicellariae can detach and keep injecting venom.

data.name: Giant carpet anemone
data.behavior: Very sticky; often half-buried with expanded oral disc.
data.description: Shaggy tentacles; hosts several anemonefish species.
data.funFact: Can irritate skin—avoid touching even when tempting!

data.name: Giant moray
data.behavior: Nocturnal ambush predator; retreats in crevices; bites if provoked.
data.description: Giant moray: common reefs near Tulamben (caution needed) in Bali
data.funFact: Cooperative hunts with groupers

data.name: Giant trevally (GT)
data.behavior: Fast pelagic hunter; patrols currents and drop-offs.
data.description: Giant trevally (GT): occasional lagoons near Nusa Penida (caution needed) in Bali
data.funFact: Apex reef predator; clever hunting

data.name: Green turtle
data.behavior: Calm grazer; surfaces to breathe; site-faithful.
data.description: Green turtle: common reefs near Nusa Penida in Bali
data.funFact: Adults mainly herbivorous

data.name: Grey reef shark
data.behavior: Pelagic reef predator; patrols drop-offs; wary.
data.description: Grey reef shark: occasional outer reef slopes near Nusa Penida in Bali
data.funFact: Threat posture when agitated

data.name: Hard Coral
data.description: Identified as Hard Coral

data.name: Hard corals (stony corals)
data.behavior: Framework builders; nightly polyp extension to feed.
data.description: Primary reef builders; diversity and cover vary by site and currents.
data.reproduction: Mass spawning events; asexual budding grows colonies.
data.funFact: Bali participates in synchronized coral-spawning nights after full moons.

data.name: Harlequin shrimp
data.behavior: Pairs cooperate to flip and immobilize sea stars.
data.description: Ornate cream-and-purple pattern; iconic macro subject.
data.reproduction: Pairs; female carries egg masses under abdomen.
data.funFact: Will feed a starfish arm to keep prey alive and fresh.

data.name: Indo-Pacific bottlenose dolphin
data.behavior: Highly social pods; bow-riding and foraging around current lines.
data.description: Smaller bottlenose with speckled belly in adults; frequent coastal visitor.
data.reproduction: Single calf ~12-month gestation; calving every 3–6 years; extended maternal care.
data.migration: Resident and short-range movements along straits and coasts.
data.funFact: Uses signature whistles—names—to keep track of pod mates.

data.name: Indo-Pacific sergeant (sergeant major)
data.description: Identified as Indo-Pacific sergeant (sergeant major)

data.name: Lace bryozoans
data.behavior: Bushy colonies with tiny zooids operating like a city.
data.description: Often mistaken for seaweeds; fine branching ‘lace’ fans.
data.reproduction: Brooded larvae released to settle nearby.
data.migration: Sessile; fouling colonies spread via larvae/rafts
data.funFact: Some Bugula produce bioactive compounds under study.

data.name: Long-tentacle plate coral
data.behavior: Sessile
data.description: Free-living single polyp resembling anemone. Iconic in aquarium trade.
data.funFact: Free-living single polyp resembling anemone

data.name: Lyretail anthias (female)
data.description: Identified as Lyretail anthias (female)

data.name: Magnificent sea anemone
data.behavior: Hosts multiple clownfish species; can slowly move to better light.
data.description: Large, colorful anemone forming showy mounds on current-swept peaks.
data.migration: Sessile but capable of creeping relocation.
data.funFact: Some individuals can span a full meter across.

data.name: Manta Ray
data.behavior: Migratory
data.description: One of the largest brains among fishes, found at cleaning stations. They are gentle giants that feed on plankton.
data.funFact: Have the largest brain-to-body ratio of any fish

data.name: Masked Butterflyfish
data.description: Identified as Masked Butterflyfish

data.name: Mimic octopus
data.behavior: Sediment flats; imitates other animals; diurnal.
data.description: Mimic octopus: occasional muck near Amed (caution needed) in Bali
data.funFact: Imitates lionfish, flatfish, sea snake

data.name: Moorish Idol
data.description: Identified as Moorish Idol

data.name: Ocean sunfish (mola)
data.behavior: Pelagic drifter; seasonal; visits cleaning stations; shy.
data.description: Ocean sunfish (mola): rare deep pelagic near Nusa Penida in Bali
data.endangered: Not clearly assessed; related spp. Vulnerable
data.funFact: Often miscalled M. mola; Bali is M. alexandrini

data.name: Orange Anthias
data.description: Identified as Orange Anthias

data.name: Orangutan crab
data.behavior: Camouflages with long reddish setae (“hair”).
data.description: Tiny, fuzzy decorator living among anemone tentacles.
data.funFact: Often associates with the very anemone that hides it from predators.

data.name: Pantropical spotted dolphin
data.behavior: Fast, acrobatic schools; often mixed-species groups offshore.
data.description: Slender beak; adults develop heavy spotting—especially offshore form.
data.reproduction: Single calf after ~11–12 months; long juvenile period.
data.migration: Offshore movements tracking prey and currents; passes through strait.
data.funFact: Spotting increases with age—calves are almost spotless.

data.name: Peacock mantis shrimp
data.behavior: Burrower; powerful smash strikes; bright coloration.
data.description: Peacock mantis shrimp: occasional reef rubble near Tulamben in Bali
data.funFact: Sees polarized light; devastating strike

data.name: Powder Blue Tang
data.description: Identified as Powder Blue Tang

data.name: Reef manta ray
data.behavior: Filter-feeder; visits cleaning stations; gentle in currents.
data.description: Reef manta ray: occasional cleaning stations (e.g. near Nusa Penida (harmless) in Bali
data.funFact: One of the largest brains among fishes

data.name: Reef Octopus
data.behavior: Nocturnal
data.description: Masters of color and texture change, active at dusk and night. Highly intelligent and curious.
data.funFact: Can change color and texture in milliseconds

data.name: Reef stonefish
data.behavior: Sedentary ambush predator; superb camouflage; extremely venomous.
data.description: Reef stonefish: occasional reef flats near Padang Bai in Bali
data.funFact: Strikes prey in ~0.015 s

data.name: Risso’s dolphin
data.behavior: Deep diver; adults covered in white scars from social interactions and prey.
data.description: Blunt head, tall dorsal fin, grey body that whitens with age.
data.funFact: Teeth mostly in the lower jaw—unusual among dolphins.

data.name: Saltwater crocodile
data.behavior: Solitary ambush predator; capable of long sea voyages.
data.description: Very rare vagrant around Bali; extreme caution on remote coasts.
data.reproduction: Egg-laying in nests; strong parental guarding.
data.migration: Dispersal across seas; individuals can travel hundreds of km.
data.endangered: IUCN: Least Concern (protected in many nations)
data.funFact: Largest living reptile; salt glands enable life at sea.

data.name: Sandfish sea cucumber
data.diet: Detritus and microalgae ingested from sand
data.behavior: Slow deposit-feeder; often half-buried and leaves meandering feeding tracks.
data.description: Thick, pale grey-brown cucumber with irregular dark blotches and coarse texture; common on Bali flats.
data.reproduction: Broadcast spawner with planktonic larvae; widely farmed for restocking/sea ranching.
data.endangered: IUCN: Endangered (overharvested for trepang in much of its range).
data.funFact: A single sandfish can rework kilos of sand daily, cleaning and oxygenating the seabed.

data.name: Sea Anemone
data.description: Identified as Sea Anemone

data.name: Sea fan (gorgonian)
data.behavior: Fan-shaped gorgonian; filter-feeding in currents; sessile.
data.description: Sea fan (gorgonian): common walls near Menjangan (walls) (caution needed) in Bali
data.funFact: Home to pygmy seahorses in NW Bali

data.name: Sea fans (gorgonians)
data.behavior: Orient fan perpendicular to current for optimal feeding.
data.description: Large lace-like fans in reds/oranges dominate Bali walls.
data.reproduction: Broadcast spawners; colonies grow by branching.
data.funFact: Pygmy seahorses hide by matching the texture and color.

data.name: Sea Turtle
data.behavior: Solitary
data.description: Green sea turtles are ancient reptiles that can live for decades. They are excellent swimmers and can hold their breath for hours.
data.funFact: Can migrate thousands of kilometers

data.name: Sergeant Major
data.description: Identified as Sergeant Major

data.name: Short-finned pilot whale
data.behavior: Matriarchal pods; tight social bonds and mass strandings recorded worldwide.
data.description: Bulbous head, dark body; powerful, coordinated hunters.
data.reproduction: Single calf after ~15 months; long calf dependency.
data.migration: Broad roaming with prey layers; passes Indonesian straits episodically.
data.funFact: Nicknamed “cheetahs of the deep” for sprint chases on dives.

data.name: Skunk cleaner shrimp
data.diet: Ectoparasites and dead tissue from client fishes
data.behavior: Sets up conspicuous cleaning posts; fearless with large fish.
data.description: Cream stripe down a red body with long white antennae.
data.reproduction: Protandric simultaneous hermaphrodite; regularly broods eggs.
data.funFact: Will even clean divers’ cuticles if you offer a hand!

data.name: Slate pencil urchin
data.behavior: Massive blunt spines resist surf; often red or maroon.
data.description: Thick “pencil” spines up to ~10 cm; painful mechanical wounds possible.
data.funFact: Spines were historically used as writing “pencils.”

data.name: Snake sea cucumber
data.diet: Deposit-feeder; picks up detritus and microalgae with sticky feeding tentacles
data.behavior: Very long, rope-like body; slow crawler with tiny 'anchor' hooks in the skin; harmless and very fragile—don’t handle.
data.description: Banded, snake-like sea cucumber that coils on shallow flats and lagoon edges; often mistaken for a sea snake.
data.reproduction: Broadcast spawner with planktonic larvae; no Cuvierian tubules.
data.funFact: Can reach 3 m and still squeeze through tiny gaps by softening its body.

data.name: Snowflake moray
data.behavior: Often active at dusk; tolerant of very shallow water.
data.description: Pale body with yellow-black ‘snowflake’ blotches; chunky head and jaws.
data.reproduction: External spawner; larvae drift before settling on reefs.
data.funFact: More of a crustacean specialist than many morays.

data.name: Soft Coral
data.description: Identified as Soft Coral

data.name: Soft Coral (Tree soft coral)
data.description: Identified as Soft Coral (Tree soft coral)

data.name: Spanish dancer nudibranch
data.behavior: Graceful undulating swimming when disturbed.
data.description: Large red dorid nudibranch; bright egg ribbons on reefs.
data.reproduction: Hermaphroditic; spiral egg ribbons on substrate.
data.funFact: Hosts commensal shrimp that match its red coloration.

data.name: Sperm whale
data.diet: Large squids and fish at great depths
data.behavior: Extreme deep diver using powerful echolocation clicks.
data.description: Largest toothed whale with massive square head.
data.reproduction: Single calf after ~14–16 months; slow population growth.
data.migration: Long-distance seasonal movements; rare in the strait.
data.funFact: Produces the ocean’s loudest biological sound.

data.name: Spinner dolphin
data.behavior: Offshore pods; acrobatic spins; approaches boats.
data.description: Spinner dolphin: common offshore near Lovina offshore (dawn) in Bali
data.funFact: Acrobatic spinning leaps

data.name: Spotted eagle ray
data.behavior: Glides over sand flats; digs for mollusks; shy.
data.description: Spotted eagle ray: occasional coastal reefs near Nusa Penida (drifts) (caution needed) in Bali
data.funFact: Digs with snout for prey

data.name: Staghorn coral (branching)
data.behavior: Sessile branching coral; fast-growing; wave-exposed zones.
data.description: Staghorn coral (branching): common shallow flats near Menjangan (caution needed) in Bali
data.funFact: Fast‑growing habitat former

data.name: Sun coral (azooxanthellate)
data.behavior: Azooxanthellate; polyps open at night; non-photosynthetic.
data.description: Sun coral (azooxanthellate): common wrecks near Tulamben (caution needed) in Bali
data.funFact: Lacks symbionts; must capture food

data.name: Tiger cowry
data.behavior: Nocturnal; mantle fully covers and polishes the shell.
data.description: Large, glossy spotted cowry; prized shell but common regionally.
data.reproduction: Female broods egg capsules under her foot.
data.funFact: Hawaiian forms include giants over 13 cm.

data.name: Titan triggerfish
data.behavior: Territorial nester; may charge; avoid during breeding.
data.description: Titan triggerfish: common reefs near Nusa Penida (caution needed) in Bali
data.funFact: Chases divers from nest cone

data.name: Tuxedo urchin
data.behavior: Often carries shells or leaves on its body for camouflage and shade.
data.description: Small, banded urchin with orange/red short spines over dark wedges; common in Bali shallows.
data.reproduction: Broadcast spawner; larvae drift as plankton before settling
data.funFact: Nicknamed 'tuxedo' for its neat wedge pattern.

data.name: Upside-down jellyfish
data.behavior: Rests bell-down on sand, pulsing to circulate water and light.
data.description: Brownish frilly oral arms; can cause mild stings (“sea rash”).
data.reproduction: Alternates polyp and medusa stages; budding and sexual reproduction.
data.migration: None; may bloom seasonally in lagoons.
data.funFact: Can create mucus “stinging water” that irritates swimmers.

data.name: Vase sponge
data.diet: Filters bacteria and plankton from seawater
data.behavior: Colonies of small tubular 'vases' with a single osculum each; steady pumping flow.
data.description: Small olive-green tubular sponges common in Bali shallows; pitted surface and single opening are typical.
data.reproduction: Broadcast spawning plus asexual budding/regrowth from fragments
data.funFact: A fist-sized sponge can filter liters of water every minute.

data.name: Wedge sea hare
data.diet: Grazes algae on sand and seagrass
data.behavior: Slow, nocturnal grazer; can release purple ink when stressed.
data.description: Bulky sea hare with rough, warty skin and a hidden internal shell; very common on Bali flats.
data.reproduction: Lays long spaghetti-like egg ribbons; adults are short-lived and may die after spawning
data.funFact: Sometimes eaten in parts of Asia, but toxins from their algal diet make them a risky meal—best admired alive.

data.name: White-eyed moray
data.behavior: Crevice dweller; often seen out in the open by day around cleaning stations.
data.description: Slender dark moray with pale eyes and fine peppery speckles; very common in Bali shallows.
data.reproduction: Broadcast spawner; leptocephalus larvae drift weeks–months before settling.
data.migration: None; generally site-faithful to a home crevice.
data.funFact: Will let cleaner shrimps crawl into its mouth to pick parasites.

data.name: Whitetip reef shark
data.behavior: Nocturnal benthic rover; rests in caves by day.
data.description: Whitetip reef shark: common reefs near Tulamben (harmless) in Bali
data.funFact: Can rest on bottom (buccal pumping)

data.name: Wunderpus
data.behavior: Striking orange-brown and white pattern; crepuscular hunter.
data.description: Delicate, long-armed octopus popular with macro photographers.
data.funFact: Individuals can be ID’d by unique head-spot patterns.

data.name: Yellow Tang
data.description: Identified as Yellow Tang

data.name: Yellow-bellied sea snake
data.behavior: Truly pelagic; aggregates in calm slicks driven by currents.
data.description: Black top, bright yellow belly; occasionally drifts into Bali waters.
data.funFact: Can absorb oxygen through skin—helpful at the surface.

data.name: Zebra moray
data.behavior: Shy daytime hider; uses crushing molar-like teeth rather than sharp fangs.
data.description: Thick body with bold black-and-white bands from head to tail.
data.reproduction: Broadcast spawner; long-lived leptocephalus larvae drift with currents.
data.funFact: Its blunt teeth are perfect nutcrackers for urchins and crabs.
